channel.title: RNZ New Zealand Headlines
channel.description: The Latest New Zealand headlines from RNZ News

item.title: Live Covid-19 updates from New Zealand and around the world on 9 June
item.description: Citizens and residents will no longer need to travel with their overseas partners and children in order for them to return to New Zealand. Follow our blog for more updates.

item.title: Teachers vote no confidence in Teaching Council over fee increase
item.description: Anger at a jump in registration fees has prompted secondary teachers to vote no confidence in their own professional body, the Teaching Council.

item.title: Manual contact tracing systems are 'completely unacceptable' - epidemiologist
item.description: New Zealand's contact tracing system is far from state of the art and still needs a lot of improvement, says an epidemiologist.

item.title: Weather: Freezing conditions on the way for weekend
item.description: The South Island can expect temperatures as low as -15 this weekend.

item.title: Police search for convicted killer in Canterbury
item.description: Melissa Wepa has a warrant for her arrest.

item.title: NZ's last hospitalised Covid-19 patient says she's lucky to be alive
item.description: When New Zealand's last hospitalised Covid-19 patient was sedated in ICU for over a month, doctors feared she would not survive and told her family to prepare to say their goodbyes.

item.title: New public housing apartments open in Onehunga
item.description: Seventy-one public housing apartments have opened in Onehunga, replacing more than 30 terrace houses.

item.title: Grandmother killed in Raetihi farm accident 'a very caring person'
item.description: Locals in Raetihi say the community will be there to help the family get through the deaths of a much-loved grandmother and her two grandsons.

item.title: Pedestrian hit by vehicle in Auckland dies of injuries
item.description: A man who was hit by a vehicle on Great South Road, Papatoetoe, has died.

item.title: Christchurch school investigating after Black Lives Matter posters torn down
item.description: An elite Christchurch private school is investigating after students reported that a teacher tore down posters and verbally abused them for promoting the Black Lives Matter movement.

item.title: Covid-19: What you need to know about alert level 1
item.description: New Zealand will move to alert level 1 from midnight, meaning social and business restrictions will be lifted, but tight border controls remain in place.

item.title: Doctors forced to apologise after failing to diagnose rectal cancer
item.description: Three doctors at a medical centre have been forced to apologise to a dead man's wife after failing to diagnose him with rectal cancer.

item.title: Nelson pharmacy and director fined $394,000 for price-fixing prescriptions
item.description: Wellington High Court has ordered a Nelson pharmacy and one of its directors to pay $394,000 in fines for price-fixing.

item.title: Dunedin scraps controversial 10km/h central city speed limits
item.description: The speed limit cuts made after the Covid-19 lockdown in central Dunedin raised the ire of many and were largely ignored.

item.title: Covid-19 work flexibility improves accessibility for people with disabilites
item.description: More flexibility with hours and working from home will help people with physical and intellectual challenges to be a part of the workforce, disability advocates say.

item.title: Hawke's Bay DHB 'multiple systems failures' led to man's death - commissioner
item.description: "Multiple systems failures" and an "IT issue" at Hawke's Bay District Health Board led to a man's delayed cancer treatment and death, the Health and Disability Commissioner has found.

item.title: Fight for better protection of pigs goes to the High Court
item.description: SAFE and the NZ Animal Law Association have gone to the High Court in their bid to improve the protection of farmed pigs.

item.title: Napier water at 'high risk' of contamination - review
item.description: A review of Napier's water supply has identified several risks, including the catastrophic scenario of the city running out of water.
